messages.subject: Re: Takeda Shingen & Uetsugi Kenshin symbolism
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you very much.  I found a picture of Takeda with antlers on-line too. The only reference I can find to a Uesugi Kenshin maedate though mentions a
messages.messageBody:
Thank you very much. I found a picture of Takeda with antlers on-line too.
The only reference I can find to a Uesugi Kenshin maedate though mentions a
crescent moon.

There is a 1990 film by Kadokawa Haruki, called in English: Heaven and
Earth, originally: Ten To Chi To, which I've seen on cable, focussing on the
Takeda-Uesugi battles.

You're right, Milt. I agree: same design, same hand. Congratulations, Mr. Haynes (certainly a good authority) rates this as "fine, classical Kyo Shoami work."

From: bungotakadasword
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2005 11:24 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Takeda Shingen & Uetsugi Kenshin symbolism



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "David Zincavage" <jdz@i...> wrote:
> Yes, it's not easy to see how maple leaves or deer antlers are "swift
as wind, fierce as fire, immovable as mountain," or Takeda or Uesugi
related.
>
> Come to think of it, Milt, you were the underbidder on that very
tsuba.

Yes, I remember that well. I have a tsuba with monkey on a peach tree.
The elements are different from yours ( monkey vs deer, different
tree ), of course, but the silhouette is identical ( that is, if you
darken to obscure the detail, the two tsuba would look the same ).
I have seen your tsuba at Ron's table...........

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Takeda Shingen & Uetsugi Kenshin symbolism
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, it s not easy to see how maple leaves or deer antlers are swift as wind, fierce as fire, immovable as mountain, or Takeda or Uesugi related. Come to
messages.messageBody:
Yes, it's not easy to see how maple leaves or deer antlers are "swift as wind, fierce as fire, immovable as mountain," or Takeda or Uesugi related.

Come to think of it, Milt, you were the underbidder on that very tsuba. Haynes [sale 5: item 63] illustrates a virtually identical tsuba, differing slightly in dimensions (Haynes' is a little smaller). Also Haynes' maple leaves have gold nunome highlights, while my tsuba retains traces of red pigment. I called mine Shoami, and described it as mid-to late Edo, while Haynes identifies his as Kyo Shoami, and attributes it specifically to Genroku.

If you'd like to compare them. mine is at:

http://www.zincavage.org/DeerandMaple.html

I'll soon be adding the Haynes picture for comparison, and modifying the text.


----- Original Message -----
From: MuramasaIII@...
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2005 9:28 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Takeda Shingen & Uetsugi Kenshin symbolism



In a message dated 4/13/2005 11:01:25 A.M. Central Daylight Time,
jdz@... writes:

when I finally obtained a copy of the 5th Haynes Auction Catalogue from the
1980s. Mr. Haynes listed an almost identical tsuba, I would say clearly
from the same hand, stating that these were symbols of the battles between
Takeda Shingen and Uesugi Kenshin. So I was trying to pursue that lead.




I fail to see the connection but then Haynes is Haynes..........
if there's an " animal connection ", then it should be a tree and a bird (
woodpecker ? ). Recall that battle when the Takada diverted part of the army
to sneak attack the castle where Uesugi was holding up ? Except when they
arrived, the Uesugi already left in the fog, crossed the river and attack the
Takada base camp. Same battle as Shingen blocked Kenshin's sword with his war
fan.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Takeda Shingen & Uetsugi Kenshin symbolism
messages.msgSnippet: I was working on more elaborate descriptions of some tsuba I own, and had discussed a particular Deer Antler & Maple Leaf in just those terms, A famous herd
messages.messageBody:
I was working on more elaborate descriptions of some tsuba I own, and had discussed a particular Deer Antler & Maple Leaf in just those terms,

"A famous herd of tame deer has been associated with the Kasuga Shrine - Kofukuji Temple complex, founded in Nara by the Fujiwara family in 709 A.D., for centuries. According to Shinto legend, the kami of Kashima Jinja (in modern Ibaraki Prefecture) and Katori Jinja (in Chiba Prefecture), were summoned by the head of the Fujiwara clan, and arrived riding on white deer for installation in the new shrine. The notion of deer serving as means of passage for divinities to the world of men enters into Shinto from Taoism. In Taoist belief, deer are the only animal able to locate the sacred Fungus of Immortality [reishi, mannendake] and live to an exceptionally old age. Deer are, therefore, the messengers of the gods of immortality, Furukokuju and Jurojin. By the 17th century, the antlers of the resident deer were deemed hazardous to the crowds of visitors to the temple and shrine, and the ceremonial cutting of the antlers (Shika-no-Tsunkiri) became an annual October event. The combination of deer antler and maple is a wonderful example of the allusive seasonal imagery beloved in Japan."



when I finally obtained a copy of the 5th Haynes Auction Catalogue from the 1980s. Mr. Haynes listed an almost identical tsuba, I would say clearly from the same hand, stating that these were symbols of the battles between Takeda Shingen and Uesugi Kenshin. So I was trying to pursue that lead.

Thanks,
David
----- Original Message -----
From: Dr John P Lissenden
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, April 13, 2005 8:38 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Takeda Shingen & Uetsugi Kenshin symbolism



Dear David

This is not really an answer to your query but Edmunds, in
his 'Pointers and Clues to the Subjects of Chinese and Japanese Art',
describes The Maple with deer as being the emblem of autumn.

Regards, John L.

messages.messageBody:
Dear David

This is not really an answer to your query but Edmunds, in
his 'Pointers and Clues to the Subjects of Chinese and Japanese Art',
describes The Maple with deer as being the emblem of autumn.

Regards, John L.
